question: I knew this was gonna be a lousy day.
answer: Personally, I would like to surrender. Why can we not just surrender?

question: Shut-up and gimme your bandolier.
answer: Then let's run away. Right now. While we can still make it.

question: Now gimme your revolver, you'll never use it anyway.
answer: Then let's play dead, huh? Nobody ever does that anymore.

question: Now go find me a big stick.
answer: In the desert? What for?

question: So I can tie it to your back, you appear to be without a spine. How'd a guy like you end up in the Legion anyways?
answer: I got caught robbing a synagogue. Lots of good stuff in them holy places; churches, temples, mosques, and who's guarding them?

question: Altar boys?
answer: Exactly! I speak seven languages, including Hebrew, so my specialty was synagogues. How about you? Kill somebody?

question: No, but I'm considering it.
answer: What then? Robbery? Extortion? Kidnapping!

question: None of the above, thank you.
answer: Then what the hell are you doing here!?

question: Tuthmosis?... Now how did you get up here? OHEIUGM!! AHHHHHH! Oops.
answer: Look at this! Sons of the Messiah! Give me frogs, flies, locusts, anything but this! Compared to you, the other plagues were a joy!

question: I'm sorry, it was an accident.
answer: When Ramesses destroyed Syria, it was an accident. You are a catastrophe! Why do I put up with you?

question: You put up with me, because I can read and write ancient Egyptian, decipher hieroglyphs and hieratic, and I'm the only person within a thousand miles who knows how to properly code and catalogue this library.
answer: Who needs smart women? I put up with you because your mother and father were our finest patrons, Allah rest their souls. Now straighten up this mess!

question: Hello? Abdul? Mohammed? Bob? You...! YOU...!
answer: Drunkard? Fool? Rat-bastard? Please call me something original.

question: Have you no respect for the dead?
answer: Right now, I only wish to join them.

question: Well I wish you'd do it sooner rather than later, before you ruin my career the way you've ruined yours.
answer: My dear, sweet, baby sister, I'll have you know, that at this moment my career is on a high note.

question: High note? Ha! For five years you've been scrounging around Egypt, and what have you to show for it? Nothing.
answer: Oh yes I do! I have something right here!

question: Oh no, not another worthless trinket, Jonathan, if I bring one more piece of junk to the Curator to try and sell for you. Where did you get this?
answer: On a dig, down in Thebes. My whole life I've never found anything, Evy. Tell me I've found something.

question: Jonathan?
answer: Yes?

question: As the Americans would say
answer: You burned it! You burned off the part with the lost city!

question: It's for the best, I'm sure. Many men have wasted their lives in the foolish pursuit of Hamunaptra, no one has ever found it, most have never returned.
answer: You killed my map.

question: You told me you found it on a dig down in Thebes!
answer: I was mistaken.

question: You lied to me!
answer: I lie to everybody, what makes you so special?

question: I'm your sister.
answer: That just makes you more gullible.

question: You stole it from a drunk at the local Casbah?!
answer: Picked his pocket, actually.

question: And what is he in prison for?
answer: I did not know, so when I heard you were coming, I asked him that myself.

question: And what did he say?
answer: He said... he was just looking for a good time.

question: I tremble with anticipation.
answer: We uh,... found... your puzzle box, and we've come to ask you about it.

question: No.
answer: No?

question: No... You came to ask me about Hamunaptra.
answer: How do you know the box pertains to Hamunaptra?

question: You were actually at Hamunaptra?
answer: I just decked your brother

question: Yes, well... I know my brother.
answer: Yeah, I was there.

question: You swear?
answer: Every damn day.

question: No, I mean --
answer: -- I know what you mean. I was there, alright. Seti's place. The City Of The Dead.

question: What did you find? What did you see?
answer: I found sand. I saw death.

question: Could you tell me how to get there? The exact location?
answer: Want to know?

question: Yes.
answer: Really want to know?

question: Yes.
answer: Then get me the hell outta here.

question: Where are they taking him?
answer: To be hanged. Apparently, he had a very good time. No women allowed.

question: I am an English woman. I will give you one hundred pounds to spare his life.
answer: I would pay one hundred pounds just to see him hang.

question: Two hundred pounds.
answer: Proceed!

question: FIVE HUNDRED POUNDS!
answer: And what else?

question: NOOO!
answer: His neck did not break! Good! Now we watch him strangle to death.

question: He knows the location to Hamunaptra.
answer: You lie.

question: I would never!
answer: Are you saying this filthy godless son of a pig knows where to find The City Of The Dead? Truly?

question: Yes and if you cut him down, we will give you ten percent.
answer: Fifty percent.

question: Twenty.
answer: Forty.

question: She must die.
answer: She is like all the others. She will die in the desert.

question: No! She has seen too much. She knows too much. Not only does she have a map, but she has the key.
answer: The key!? She has the lost key!?

question: Yes. No one has ever had so much, been so close. We must stop her, or it will be the end of us all.
answer: Then we will kill her, we will kill her and all those with her.

question: And burn the map and retrieve the key.
answer: It will be done. But what of the American expedition? They leave tomorrow as well.

question: Sorry, didn't mean to scare ya.
answer: The only thing that scares me, Mister O'Connell, are your manners.

question: Still angry that I kissed ya, huh?
answer: If you call that a kiss. Did I miss something? Are we going into battle?

question: The last time I was at that place everybody I was with died. There's something out there, you know, something under that sand.
answer: Yes, I'm hoping to find a certain artifact, a book, actually, my brother thinks there's treasure. What do you think is out there?

question: Evil. The Tuaregs and the Bedouin believe that Hamunaptra is cursed, they call it, "the doorway to hell."
answer: Ahmar is Ossirion. "Passageway to the underworld", actually. I don't believe in fairy tales and hokum, Mister O'Connell, but I do believe that one of the most famous books in history is buried out there, The Book Of The Living. It's what first interested me in Egypt as a child. It's why I came here, sort of a life's pursuit.

question: And the fact that they say it's made out of pure gold, makes no nevermind to you, right?
answer: You know your history.

question: I know my treasure.
answer: By the way,... why did you kiss me?

question: I was about to be hanged, seemed like a good idea at the time. What?... Wha'd I say?
answer: My very good friend! What a surprise.

question: Why if it ain't my little buddy, Beni. I oughta kill you.
answer: You never were any good with the ladies, O'Connell.

question: So you're the one leading the Americans, I shoulda figured. So what's the scam? You get 'em out in the middle of the desert then leave 'em to rot?
answer: Unfortunately no, these Americans are smart, they pay me only half now, half when I get them back to Cairo, so I must go all the way. You never believed in Hamunaptra, O'Connell. Why are you going back? The devil himself lives out there.

question: The girl saved my life, figured it was the least I could do, keep her out of trouble.
answer: You always did have more balls than brains.

question: Let's make us even, shall we?
answer: Even? O'Connell! I am going to kill you for this!

question: Friend of yours?
answer: The map! We need the map!

question: Relax! I'm the map! It's all up here.
answer: Oh that's comforting.

question: Hey Beni! Looks to me like your on the wrong side of the river!
answer: I can't believe the price of these fleabags.

question: We coulda had 'em for free, all we had to do was give 'em your sister.
answer: Yes, awfully tempting, wasn't it?

question: Awfully. Then again...
answer: Never did like camels. Filthy buggers. They smell, they bite, they spit. Disgusting.

question: Be nice. That thing saved my life.
answer: That "thing" gets me excited.

question: The things that get you excited.
answer: According to Bembridge Scholars, inside the statue of Anubis was a secret compartment, perhaps containing The Book Of The Living.

question: What are those mirrors for?
answer: Ancient Egyptian trick. You'll see. Do you realize, we are standing inside a room that no one has entered in over four thousand years.

question: Cretins.
answer: That is a neat trick.

question: Oh my god, It's a preparation room.
answer: Preparation for what?

question: I believe in being prepared.
answer: Seagrams! Well, he may have been a stinky fellow,... but he had good taste.

question: Stay here!
answer: Evy! Excuse me! But didn't the man just say -- !

question: Goin' somewhere?
answer: Just looking for you, O'Connell! I wanted to be with my friend!

question: C'mon, friend.
answer: Why do you like to fight so much?

question: These men are a desert people. They value water, not gold.
answer: Where's Jonathan? Unlike my brother, sir, I know when to say no.

question: Unlike your brother, Miss, you I don't get. You're a whole new brew.
answer: I know, you're wondering, what's a place like me doing in a girl like this?

question: Something like that.
answer: Egypt is in my blood. My father was a famous explorer, he loved Egypt so much that he married an Egyptian. My mother! Who was quite an adventurer herself

question: Okay, I get your father, I get your mother and I get your brother, but what are you doing here?
answer: I may not be an explorer, or an adventurer, or a treasure hunter, or a gunfighter! Mister O'Connell But I'm proud of what I am.

question: And what is that?
answer: ...I am a librarian! I'm going to kiss you, Mister O'Connell.

question: No you're not.
answer: I'm not?

question: Not unless you call me Rick.
answer: Why would I do that?

question: Yeah, who cares.
answer: In these hallowed grounds, that which was set forth in ancient times, is as strong today, as it was then.

question: Yeah, yeah, okay, what's it --
answer: "Death will come on swift wings to whomever opens this chest". It says, there is one, the undead, who if brought back to life, is bound by sacred law to consummate this curse.

question: Yeah, well, let's just make sure we don't bring anybody back from the dead then, huh?
answer: He will kill all who open this chest,... and assimilate their organs and fluids.

question: Must of got a little too frisky with the Pharaoh's daughter.
answer: According to my readings, our friend suffered the HOM-DAI, the worst of all ancient Egyptian curses, one reserved for only the most evil blasphemers. In all of my research, I've never read of this curse actually having been performed.

question: That bad huh?
answer: Yes, they never used it because they feared it so. It's written, that if a victim of the HOM-DAI should ever arise, he would bring with him the ten plagues of Egypt.

question: Ahhhhhhhh!!
answer: I told you to leave or die, you refused, and now you may have killed us all. For you have unleashed the creature that we have feared for more than four thousand years.

question: Relax, I got him.
answer: No mortal weapons can kill this creature. He is not of this world.

question: I thought you didn't believe in this stuff!?
answer: Having an encounter with a four thousand year old walking-talking corpse tends to convert one.

question: Forget it, we're out the door down the hall and gone.
answer: No, we are not.

question: Oh yes we are.
answer: No we are not. We woke him up, and we must try and stop him.

question: We?! What we?! You didn't read that book. I told you not to play around with that thing.
answer: Alright then, Me, I,... I read the book, I woke him up and I intend to stop him.

question: How!? You heard the man, no mortal weapons can kill this guy.
answer: Then we'll have to find some immortal ones.

question: There goes that belief again. Not me, I am outta here!
answer: According to that Book, once this creature has been reborn, his curse will spread, and as he grows in strength, so will his curse grow, infecting the people until the whole of the earth is destroyed.

question: Yeah? So? Is that my problem?
answer: It's everybody's problem!

question: Look lady, I appreciate you saving my life and all, but when I signed on, I agreed to take you out there and bring you back, and I did, now were even, end of job, end of story, contract terminated.
answer: That's what I am to you? A contract?

question: You can either tag along with me, or you can stay here and play around with Mister Maggot.
answer: I'm staying.

question: Beni ya little stinkweed, where did you slink off to?
answer: You left me! You left me in the desert to rot.

question: Oh yeah,... sorry bout that. So who's this guy?
answer: This is Prince Imhotep, High Priest of Osiris.

question: Oh, hey, how ya doin'?
answer: The Prince does not like to be touched by other humans. A Silly eastern superstition, I'm afraid.

question: Yeah, well, we all got our little problems today don't we?
answer: He has come to help Mister Burns. Somehow I feel responsible.

question: Don't gimme that, you never had any scruples.
answer: Do you know where I can steal some?

question: Blood.
answer: "And the rivers and waters of Egypt went red and were as blood."

question: He's here.
answer: Who's here!?

question: Do you truly wish to know? Or would you prefer to just shoot us?
answer: I just saw my fist vanish into some guy's head. I'm willin, to go on a little faith, here.

question: You will not believe it.
answer: Try me.

question: Well, well, well. Lemme guess, spring cleaning? Where's your new friend?
answer: What friend? You're my only friend.

question: Then you got no excuse for living. What the hell you doin, being buddies with this creep, Beni? What's in it for you?
answer: It is better to be the right hand of the Devil,... than in his path. As long as I serve him, I am immune.

question: Immune from what?
answer: You shall see.

question: What are you looking for? Lie, and I'll slit your throat.
answer: The book! The black book they found at Hamunaptra! Imhotep wants it back. Said to me it would be worth it's weight in diamonds.

question: What does he want the book for?
answer: Something about bringing his dead girly-friend back to life. He needs the book... And your sister.

question: That looked rather painful.
answer: Ya know, ever since I met you, my luck has been for crap.

question: Yes, I know, I do that to people.
answer: Damn-it! That's two down and only two to go.

question: Get your hands off my girl, pal. Nice lips. I figured you might be here, so I brought a friend.
answer: You called me your girl?

question: What?... Oh yeah, that was just um, you know, figure a speech.
answer: I think you were jealous

question: Yes. To Hamunaptra. To perform the ritual.
answer: And what ritual would that be?

question: The ritual to bring the body of Anck- su-namun back to life.
answer: And how does one do that?

question: By reading the Book Of The Dead.
answer: Oh yes, of course.

question: And then killing your sister.
answer: Excuse me?

question: Imhotep is now able to cross the desert with great haste.
answer: Begging your pardon, but I wasn't quite clear on that last part.

question: If he arrives before us, it will be too late.
answer: Did you say 'kill' my sister?

question: I know how to beat him to it.
answer: So what's your little problem got to do with His Majesty's Royal Air Corp?

question: Not a god-damned thing.
answer: Is it dangerous?

question: You probably won't live through it.
answer: By Jove, do you really think so?

question: Prince Imhotep wants your heart.
answer: Tell him, I'm truly flattered... but that it's already taken.

question: He wants your heart and your brain, your liver, your kidneys... ...and how do you say? Those slimy things, in your stomach?
answer: Intestines.

question: Yeah! Them.
answer: You only want me for my organs?!

question: Who the hell are these guys?
answer: Priests. Imhotep's priests.

question: I never killed a priest before.
answer: They are evil, cursed, they matter not.

question: I found it, Evy! I found it
answer: Shut-up and get me off of here! Open the book, Jonathan! Open the book! That's the only way to kill him!

question: I can't open it! It's locked or something! We need the key! What do I do, Evy!? What do I do!?
answer: Read the inscription on the cover!

question: You have got to be joking?
answer: Finish the inscription, idiot!

question: Oh. Ummm, Hootash im... Hootash im now what is this last symbol here?
answer: What's it look like!?

question: It's an Anck symbol, with two little squiggly lines above it, and a bird, a stork! on either side.
answer: Ah! Ah! Ahmenophus!
